title: U.S. Military Acknowledges Kabul Drone Strike Killed 10 Civilians
summary: Pentagon, in reversal, says airstrike failed to hit Islamic State militants as intended. WASHINGTON-The U.S. military said Friday that it mistakenly killed at least 10 Afghan civilians, including seven children-but not an Islamic State terrorist, as intended-when it launched a drone strike on a car in Kabul last month.

title: Ginkgo Bioworks Goes Public After Closing SPAC Merger
summary: Synthetic-biology company raises $1.6 billion through the transaction with a special-purpose acquisition company. Shares of synthetic-biology company Ginkgo Bioworks Holdings Inc. rose on their first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, following the closing of its merger with a blank-check company.

title: Bad Advice on Covid Vaccine Boosters
summary: The FDA's advisory panel downplays growing evidence of waning antibodies.. A Food and Drug Administration advisory panel on Friday voted to recommend Pfizer Covid-19 booster shots for Americans over age 65 and those at "high risk," but not for the broader population. What do these public-health experts have against individuals making up their own minds about their own health?

title: Private Astronauts Float Through Orbit With Video Calls, Cold Pizza, Earth Views
summary: SpaceX says it plans to land crew Saturday in the waters off Florida just after 7 p.m.. SpaceX's crew of private astronauts has spent its first two days in space chatting with children, conducting research and taking in views of the planet hundreds of miles away.

title: Ex-Theranos Chemist Says Holmes Was Aware of Testing Failures
summary: Surekha Gangakhedkar testifies she left the blood-testing startup because problem-plagued machines were being rushed out. SAN JOSE, Calif.-A chemist who worked at Theranos Inc. testified Friday about the scientific failures that plagued the defunct blood-testing startup, as the high-stakes fraud case wrapped up a second week of witness testimony in a federal courthouse.

title: The Deadly Kabul Mistake
summary: A tragic lesson in the limits of Biden's 'over-the-horizon' strategy.. The Pentagon acknowledged Friday that a U.S. drone strike killed innocent civilians on Aug. 29 amid the frantic American exit from Afghanistan. The admission is welcome, but Congress should still investigate how the decision to target a nonterrorist was made and if the White House played any role.

title: Green Welfare for the Rich
summary: Democrats plus up the EV tax credit-and more for union-made cars.. What Democrats' $3.5 trillion budget bill taketh from affluent Americans in higher taxes, it giveth some back in green welfare. Behold their gussied-up $12,500 electric-vehicle handout.

title: At Sequoia National Park, Giant Trees Wrapped in Foil as Nearby Wildfires Grow
summary: General Sherman Tree and others in California are threatened by KNP Complex blaze. Firefighters covered some of the giant trees of California's Sequoia National Park in protective foil as growing wildfires threatened one of the state's most well-known groves.

title: Tech Billionaires Ignore the Philanthropy of Things
summary: Donors can do more by investing in amenities that are available to all, not nebulous social causes.. We live in an age of megaphilanthropy. Big name Silicon Valley billionaires channel their fortunes into social causes ranging from poverty and healthcare to education and gender equality. Two philanthropic New Yorkers have taken a different path, steering clear of lofty causes in favor of tangible, physical contributions to improve the life of their city.

title: We Must Pass the Infrastructure Bill
summary: Unlike the Democrats's reckless $3.5 trillion spending spree, these investments are vital to the country's future.. The devastation left by Hurricane Ida has brought the national debate about America's dilapidated infrastructure into clearer perspective. Everyone digging out from Ida's wrath understands that small businesses and budding industries can't thrive if the electricity grid is down and roads are impassable due to flooding. Without effective, safe and secure infrastructure, there is no foundation to rebuild, and economic growth is difficult to achieve.

title: Durham Delivers on Russiagate
summary: The indictment of a Democratic lawyer points in too many directions for the story to end here.. If you thought the invention and peddling of the Trump-Russia conspiracy deserved a reckoning, it may have started on Thursday.

title: U.S. Safety Agency to Probe Fatal Tesla Crash in Florida
summary: National Transportation Safety Board has been interested in electric-vehicle fires for some time. The top U.S. crash investigator said it was opening an investigation into the fatal crash of a Tesla Inc. Model 3 car that hit a tree in Florida this week.

title: Rare Copy of U.S. Constitution to Be Auctioned
summary: Document is one of 11 surviving copies first printed for delegates at Constitutional Convention and for Continental Congress. A rare, first-edition copy of the U.S. Constitution will soon go to the highest bidder.

title: Ex-Mylan Executive Pleads Guilty Over Insider-Trading Allegations
summary: Dayakar Mallu received illicit tips on drug approvals, earnings and merger. WASHINGTON-A former technology executive of generic drugmaker Mylan NV pleaded guilty Friday to allegations that he illicitly traded in the company's securities using tips from another company insider.

title: Dozens Charged With Healthcare Fraud Estimated at $1.4 Billion
summary: Allegations from Justice Department involve claims related to opioids, telemedicine practices and Covid-19. The Justice Department has brought criminal charges against nearly 140 people, including medical professionals, for alleged healthcare fraud schemes that resulted in an estimated $1.4 billion in losses.

title: North Carolina Court Strikes Down Voter ID Law
summary: Judges say measure is unconstitutional and discriminatory toward Black voters. Judges in North Carolina blocked a state voter-identification law Friday, calling the measure unconstitutional and discriminatory toward Black voters.

title: When Hawaii Asked Tourists to Postpone, Many Listened
summary: With trips getting delayed until 2022, hospitality workers face reduced hours and wages. Many tourists heeded the calls of Hawaii's governor to put off trips to the islands. Now, locals are wondering what the coming months will bring.

title: Kyrgyzstan Blocked From London Gold Trading Over Missing Bars
summary: Decision likely stops gold-dependent central Asian economy from selling bullion in international hubs. The organization that oversees London's gold trading blocked metal mined in Kyrgyzstan from entering the city's market, dealing a blow to the central Asian nation's bullion-dependent economy.

title: A Comrade in the Crosshairs
summary: In George Orwell's 'Homage to Catalonia,' the writer looks back on his service in the Spanish Civil War and the way Communists turned against their allies.

title: Biden to Host Global Covid-19 Virtual Summit
summary: White House says the president will focus on vaccinating the world and making oxygen, therapeutics and personal protective equipment available. President Biden will host a virtual summit of world leaders and global health officials next week on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly, the White House said Friday.

title: Stocks Finish Lackluster Week With a Down Day
summary: Equities have wavered as investors grapple with mixed economic data, impact of Delta variant's spread. U.S. stocks fell and bond yields rose as new data on consumer sentiment was slightly below expectations, raising fresh questions about the pace of economic growth and the inflation outlook.

title: D.C. Rally for Jan. 6 Rioters Prompts Increased Security
summary: Fences go up again at U.S. Capitol ahead of Saturday's 'Justice for J6' demonstration. WASHINGTON-Authorities on Friday warned of threats of violence associated with a Saturday rally of Trump supporters planning to "demand justice" for the hundreds of people charged in the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol, as police stepped up security to prepare for possible clashes and unrest.

title: Does Everyone Need a Covid-19 Booster Shot? Here's What Scientists Say
summary: Booster shots are likely low risk, doctors say. Whether generally healthy people need them is less clear.. Some people are trying to get Covid-19 booster shots. Others aren't sure if they need them. Mixed public health messages aren't making personal-health decisions any clearer.

title: Black Children More Likely to Have Appendectomy Complications, Study Finds
summary: Racial disparity in rate of ruptures leads to higher costs for nation's healthcare system. Black children who have their appendixes removed have higher rates of complication and rupture than white children, medical researchers found.

title: White House to Extend ACA Sign-Up Period by 30 Days
summary: Officials seek to boost enrollment in health insurance plans as Covid-19 pandemic continues. The Biden administration will extend the open enrollment period under the Affordable Care Act by 30 days, giving people more time to sign up for coverage as the worsening Covid-19 pandemic contributes to upheaval in the job market where many get health insurance.

title: test
Rows Garden (Saturday Variety Puzzle, September 18)
'Succession' Season 3 Means Shiv's Power Pants Are Back
summary: Shiv Roy's high-waisted trousers aren't just chic and flattering-they're a wide-legged assertion of authority. Ahead of the HBO show's October return, how to emulate the character's style.. OBSCENE WEALTH. Family drama. Scandals galore. HBO's series "Succession," whose third season kicks off on Oct. 17, has given viewers plenty to talk about since its 2018 premiere. But no secret relationship or corporate coverup has captivated us quite like the metamorphosis of Siobhan "Shiv" Roy. Over the course of two seasons, Shiv-mogul Logan Roy's only daughter-has gone from softly tressed progressive to blunt-bobbed power player, abandoning her political career to pursue the Waystar Royco throne. And costume designer Michelle Matland made sure her wardrobe echoed that shift.

title: Edvard Munch Beyond 'The Scream'
summary: A new Oslo museum dedicated to the pioneering modern painter shows the full range of his work. The reputation of Norwegian artist Edvard Munch has never been higher. In recent decades, scholars have elevated his role in the history of art while collectors fueled an explosion in prices for his work. His best-known creation, "The Scream," is familiar to millions. Yet at Oslo's Munch Museum, gallery space was actually shrinking after a 2004 robbery forced an increase in security measures, while a series of special exhibitions edged out any permanent installation of its namesake's art.

title: In Denver, an Energy Exec's Estate With Several Man-Made Lakes Asks $21 Million
summary: Resume Subscription. In a Denver suburb, an energy executive built an elaborate 14-acre estate complete with several man-made lakes and an enormous tent decorated with rugs and chandeliers. Now the place is coming on the market for $21 million.

title: A Colorful Adobe-Style Home Outside Denver
summary: In the suburb of Greenwood Village, Colo., sits a roughly 14-acre estate with a large house painted vivid vivid shades of turquoise, golden yellow and red.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: What to Read This Week
summary: A new history of the American revolution, a novel of counterfactual conquerors, a murder in the Scottish court, the pleasure of pain and more..

title: 'The Cause' Review: Revolutionary Answers
summary: The author of 'Founding Brothers' tries to capture the breadth of the War for Independence in a single narrative.. In the summer of 1976, my family took a hot car trip in our Chevy Impala from our home in the middle of the country to be part of the bicentennial. I remember that visiting Philadelphia and colonial Williamsburg in Virginia made being an American feel tangible-a proud if vague connection to tri-cornered hats, seas of Betsy Ross flags and the spirit of '76. The 250th anniversary of the founding of the United States is coming up in 2026, and now, no less than in 1976, the country could use reminders of how difficult and important becoming a democracy was. The U.S. Semiquincentennial Commission, commissioned by Congress to commemorate the upcoming anniversary, has the mission "to catalyze a more perfect union by designing and leading the most comprehensive and inclusive celebration in our country's history." This seems like an appropriate time to read a good overview of the American Revolution, as a lesson in what happened and why it mattered.

title: The Vaccine Mandate and the State of U.S. Hospitals
summary: President Biden misidentifies the choke point in hospitals today.. Your editorial "Biden's Vaccine Command" (Sept. 11) describes as "false" the president's blaming of unvaccinated Americans for clogging up "emergency rooms and intensive care units, leaving no room for someone with a heart attack, or pancreatitis, or cancer." The president's assertion isn't entirely false, but it misidentifies the choke point in hospitals today.

title: U.S.-Australia Submarine Pact Targets China's Undersea Weakness
summary: By sharing technology, Washington will effectively augment its own Asian fleet to help deter Beijing from expansionism. Australia's decision to build eight nuclear-powered submarines with U.S. technology will buttress America's undersea edge over China and could help create a network of submarine defenses from the Indian to Pacific oceans to help deter Beijing from expansionism.

title: The Sacrifices of the War on Terror Were Not in Vain
summary: For 20 years, the American homeland was safe. Our warriors took the battle to the enemy.. Regarding your editorial "A War on Terror Accounting" (Sept. 11): I had the privilege of serving as an Army physician at Walter Reed Medical Center from 2005-10, during the height of Operation Enduring Freedom and Operation Iraqi Freedom. Two or three times a week, Air Force cargo planes full of wounded warriors would land at Andrews Air Force Base for transport to medical centers. We treated those who had been blinded, deafened, disfigured and had limbs amputated, among other injuries, not to mention the psychological scars so many bear to this day. After discharge, many struggled with alcoholism, drug abuse, depression and suicide.

title: 'Hurts So Good' Review: Pain on the Brain
summary: From extreme spices to extreme sports, the pursuits of pleasure and pain are often intermingled.. A few years ago, an Australian scientist was bushwhacking through the wilderness when he felt a twig snap against his leg. Or so he thought. He'd actually been nipped by an Eastern brown snake, one of the most venomous serpents on Earth. Oblivious, he walked on and even went swimming in a nearby river before blacking out and nearly dying.

title: Biden's Tax Increases on American Farmers
summary: Arkansas Sen. Boozman responds to Agriculture Secretary Vilsack.. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack's op-ed "Biden's Tax Changes Won't Hurt Family Farmers" (Sept. 9) should have been an opportunity to clear the air on the tax increases President Biden is pushing to fund his multitrillion dollar expansion of social programs.

title: Not So Easy to Uncook the Government Books
summary: Honest information has long been readily available. Members of Congress have chosen to ignore it.. John Steele Gordon's heart is in the right place ("How to Stop Politicians From Cooking the Books," op-ed, Sept. 13), though he is advocating something that already exists. The Treasury Department already issues an annual financial report prepared subject to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP)-the Financial Report of the United States Government-and has done so for over 20 years. The report is subject to audit by the Government Accountability Office, which issues an accompanying report. The accounting standards, established by the Federal Accounting Standards Advisory Board (FASAB), have been recognized as GAAP since 1999.

title: Is Watching TV on Your Phone Futile? A Debate
summary: For some, there's no beating the convenience of mobile viewing. To others, it's a horribly compromised version of the full TV experience. Here, we argue both sides.. For the recurring series, That's Debatable, we take on a contentious issue of the day and present two spirited arguments-one in favor and the other emphatically opposed. Previous installments from the series are here.

title: Moderna's Covid-19 Shot Best Prevents Hospitalization, Study Indicates
summary: Research showed Johnson & Johnson shot offered the least protection against hospitalization over time. The Covid-19 vaccine made by Moderna Inc. is more effective at keeping people out of the hospital than those from Pfizer Inc. and partner BioNTech SE or Johnson & Johnson, new research indicates.

title: State Funds Drop Unilever After Ben & Jerry's Israel Clash
summary: Ice cream brand's decision to stop sales in the West Bank puts pressure on U.K.-based parent company. Two months after Ben & Jerry's said it would stop retailing its products in Jewish settlements located in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, several state funds are selling or threatening to sell their investments in Unilever PLC, the ice cream brand's parent company.

title: Bernie's Broken Markets
summary: The time to worry is when the senator is not criticizing your economy.. Sen. Bernie Sanders (socialist, Vt.) is still insisting that the U.S. economy is in need of a gargantuan $3.5 trillion overhaul. Are things really that bad? Other than threats from government debt and inflation created by the senator and his Washington colleagues, it's not easy to spot problems in an economy where job openings have never been more plentiful. The Journal's Josh Mitchell writes:

title: For Punishment or Penitence?
summary: Fifty years ago, the Attica uprising laid bare the conflicting ideas at the heart of the U.S. prison system. Historian Amanda Foreman searches the past for the origins of today's world. Read previous columns here.

title: Why Hidden TVs like Samsung's 'The Frame' Are Trending-and Which One to Buy
summary: Discreet, almost invisible TVs-some look like mirrors, some roll away into a base-marry elevated aesthetics with superior viewing quality. But price is a big factor.. WHEN YOU FALL on the extreme ends of the TV-consumer spectrum-either a hard-core gamer or a stubborn Luddite-choosing a set is straightforward: You go all in even if it dominates the room, or you get nothing at all. But what if, like most of us, you're somewhere in the middle? As far as off-the-rack fixes go, few are less obtrusive than the Frame- Samsung 's "lifestyle" TV designed to look just like a picture hanging on the wall. But if even a faux Modigliani is too much visual clutter for you, the Frame might not go far enough. The good news: There are alternatives. Namely, a handful of ultra-discreet sets that offer a peek at what the future of "invisible" A/V might hold. The bad news: For now, at least, they'll cost you more (sometimes, a lot more). Are they worth the splurge? We spoke with tech experts, interior designers, and savvy homeowners to find out more about the Frame and its rivals.

title: McDonald's Starts Making Self-Service Easier for Blind Diners
summary: Fast-food chain says all company-owned restaurants will offer screen-reader technology on its kiosks by the end of the year. McDonald's Corp. is upgrading some of its self-service kiosks to make them more accessible to blind people.

title: Hope for the Lost Souls of Liberalism
summary: The Western model of individual liberty and religious neutrality is in trouble. A return to the big questions is in order.. Greenville, S.C.

title: 'Banned Books Week' Isn't Actually Interested in Banned Books
summary: If it were, conservative writers like Abigail Shrier and Ryan T. Anderson would be on the list.. The annual ritual known as Banned Books Week rarely involves books that have been banned in any meaningful sense. Begun in 1982 and endorsed by such mainstream organizations as the American Library Association and PEN America, this gimmicky promotion caters primarily to those who believe that schoolchildren should have access to anything bound between two covers without the interference of those busybodies we call parents.

title: Toy Inventor Made His Name With The Game of Life
summary: Reuben Klamer, who has died at age 99, also created a version of the hula hoop, Tupperware Busy Blocks and a cotton-candy maker. In 1959, Reuben Klamer pitched his latest toy idea to Milton Bradley Co.-a kit that would teach children to create art. The company nixed that idea but asked him to try to dream up a board game.

title: Former Victoria's Secret Angel Karolina Kurkova Lists Tribeca Pad for $4.7 Million
summary: The model's 2,063-square-foot apartment underwent an extensive remodel that made it 'much more glamorous'. Karolina Kurkova is listing her apartment in New York's Tribeca district for $4.7 million.

title: Airbnb Hosts in College Towns Fumble the Big Games With Too-High Rates
summary: They want to stick it to fans of rival teams, so they raise their prices-and end up losing guests. It would seem that Airbnb hosts in college towns would earn a lot of money when the home team is hosting its biggest rival-say, a game between the University of Florida and Florida State, or the University of Michigan and Ohio State. But recent research found that for many Airbnb hosts those events are a blown opportunity to score big bucks.

title: Chinese Court Hears Single Woman's Quest to Freeze Her Eggs
summary: Despite Beijing's steps to increase births, unmarried women remain locked out of many maternity benefits. BEIJING-An unmarried Chinese woman's suit to be allowed to freeze her eggs resumed in court after a two-year hiatus, drawing fresh attention to how China's quest to boost births makes few concessions for women planning children out of wedlock.

title: World Off Track to Meet Paris Climate Targets, U.N. Says
summary: United Nations report is expected to serve as a starting point for negotiations over which countries need to do more to cut emissions. The Earth is expected to be around 2.7 degrees Celsius warmer by the end of this century than in the preindustrial era under emissions plans drafted for the Paris climate accord, the United Nations said Friday, putting the world far off track from the agreement's climate targets.

title: Karolina Kurkova's Modern Retreat in Tribeca
summary: The model extensively redesigned the space, creating a spacious foyer that she used to display art. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: How Our TV Obsession Shapes How We Eat, Dress, Travel and Live
summary: Resume Subscription. TELEVISION, AT ITS BEST, distracts from real life and doesn't judge us if we slump in front of it wearing what might charitably be called "comfortable clothes." But increasingly, as streaming outfits pour millions into ever more ambitious, Emmy-worthy productions, TV is also a great source of inspiration when it comes to our more ambitious selves. That is, the selves who want to dress, at least now and then, like Shiv Roy in "Succession" (who dominates in high-waisted power pants), eat a savory goat stew inspired by the antics of the wellness retreaters in "Nine Perfect Strangers," or model our decor after the surprisingly tasteful Vegas home of Deborah Vance, one of the titular "Hacks" in the HBO Max comedy, which is up for an Outstanding Production Design award at the Emmys this Sunday.

title: Steven Van Zandt Was an Actor Without Knowing It
summary: The guitarist for Bruce Springsteen's E Street Band found a second act as a star of 'The Sopranos'. "I think every good artist eventually asks themselves if they are being useful," says Steven Van Zandt, who has been the indispensable consigliere for two of the greatest bosses in American culture: Bruce Springsteen and Tony Soprano. In "Unrequited Infatuations," a new memoir coming out Sept. 28, Mr. Van Zandt recounts his extraordinary journey from playing guitar in Mr. Springsteein's E Street Band to playing gangster Silvio Dante in the classic HBO series "The Sopranos," as well as his work as a writer, activist and arts advocate.

title: Fiction: Laurent Binet's 'Civilizations' Review
summary: Inca conquerors land in Europe in a work of alternate history from the author of "HHhH.". The first fictional twist in Laurent Binet's magnificent counter-history "Civilizations" -the small domino that will overturn the entire course of the Western world-concerns the half-sister of Leif Erikson, who, in the wake of a family dispute, leaves Greenland for the North American shores known as Vinland. Quickly befriending and mixing with the coastal indigenous tribes, but forced to continuously sail south due to outbreaks of disease, this Freydis Eriksdottir and her entourage pass on to the native peoples an invaluable source of knowledge: the method of extracting iron from peat.

title: Chico's FAS Names Patrick Guido as Finance Chief
summary: Interim CFO David Oliver reappointed to his prior role of senior vice president of finance. Chico's FAS Inc. said it has named Patrick J. Guido as finance chief, effective Sept. 20.

title: Democrats Seek Backup Plan on Taxing Capital Gains
summary: Alternative sought after President Biden's proposal to limit the tax-free step-up basis runs into opposition. WASHINGTON-Entrenched opposition from some Democrats to a White House plan to tax unrealized capital gains at death has pushed the party to look for alternative methods of collecting additional taxes from wealthy Americans' appreciating assets.

title: 'The Sleeping Beauties' Review: Illness Beyond Medicine
summary: The enigmas of the body and mind include cases that seem to come straight out of folklore.. In 2018, a woman named Karin nearly died of a broken heart. There were no underlying diseases, no congested arteries, no signs, no symptoms-yet her heart suddenly ballooned in size and threatened to burst. If at that moment she hadn't happened to be lying on an operating table for a routine retinal procedure, she would certainly have died. Karin was later diagnosed with broken-heart syndrome, which can be caused by severe stress, sudden shock, bereavement, financial losses, even a surprise party. And it can kill you.

title: Mark Milley Says Calls to Chinese General Were Within His Duties
summary: Top U.S. general under fire over reports of talks with Chinese counterpart at end of Trump term. ATHENS-The Pentagon's top military officer, Gen. Mark Milley, said he would mount a vigorous defense of two calls he placed to his Chinese counterpart in the tumultuous last days of the Trump administration, describing an effort to calm Beijing's nerves and avert a military conflict.

title: 'Rizzio' Review: Murder at Holyrood Palace
summary: The enemies of Mary, Queen of Scots, scheme to assassinate David Rizzio, her Italian secretary.. "Rizzio," a brief novel of historical treachery by the adventurous Scottish author Denise Mina, is set mostly in Edinburgh's Holyrood Palace in early 1566. In residence at Holyrood is the 23-year-old Mary, Queen of Scots, and her husband and king consort, Lord Darnley, with whose child she is six months pregnant. Parliament is in session, about to strip the Queen's remaining rivals of their powers and lands. Those rivals-plus the "Chaseabout Lords" already exiled or slighted by Mary-have something else in mind: They plan to seize power after killing the Queen's private secretary, David Rizzio, on the premise that he's a papal spy.

title: Investing for Income in a World Without Any
summary: Billions of dollars have poured into real-estate investment trusts this year. But chasing a hot asset class can cool it off.. What's often regarded as a substitute for bonds and is up nearly 30% so far this year?

title: 'In Kiltumper' Review: A Garden Grows in Ireland
summary: On a hillside in County Clare, a garden marks a near-lost function of the landscape.. The idea that we should retreat from the world to cultivate our own gardens now seems thoroughly inadvisable. Even on our tiny patches of land, we are inextricably enmeshed with one another; there's no escaping global sorrows. This is one of several thorny dilemmas novelist Niall Williams tangles with in a moving and surprisingly provocative new memoir, "In Kiltumper: A Year in an Irish Garden." Its byways are as meandering as the garden, winding through meditations on soil, tea, varieties of rain and, this being Ireland, wandering into the mystic. Mr. Williams's wife, Christine Breen, offers brisk, often witty, running commentary; she is a knowledgeable gardener; her illustrations lend a delicate touch. This memoir won't teach you to garden, but it will show you a way of living in and through a garden. As Mr. Williams puts it, "Home is where you dig."

title: The Long History of Vaccine Mandates in America
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has revived a debate over public health and individual liberty that goes back to colonial times.. In February 1991, five Philadelphia children died from a disease thought to be almost extinct. Measles had once sickened millions of pre-adolescents, hospitalizing 50,000 and killing close to 500 annually before a successful vaccine was developed in 1963. Cases dropped dramatically after that as states began to mandate measles shots for school children. Vaccine hesitancy and resistance were rare.

title: Children's Books: 'For Every Little Thing' Review
summary: Works of poetic gratitude and sibling devotion.. At the end of a long, turbulent day, there are few things pleasanter than to curl up with a small child or two and a stack of picture books. The noise of the world subsides. Bedtime ticks closer. For as long as time allows, you can wander together through one illustrated realm after another.

title: How TV Set Designers Use Decor to Say What a Script Doesn't
summary: The creators of a luxurious home office on the set of 'Hacks' decode its knickknacks, furniture and art to reveal how they all help tell a character's story. WHILE WE'RE ALL familiar with sneaky subliminal messages in advertising (phalluses airbrushed into ice cubes!), do they occur in set design?

title: Five Best: Books on True Crime
summary: Selected by Atticus Lish, the author, most recently, of the novel 'The War for Gloria.'. By William Hoffman and Lake Headley (1993)

title: High Holy Days Poke Holes in Portfolios
summary: One of the more curious patterns in the stock market, 'sell Rosh Hashanah, buy Yom Kippur,' has struck again. The days of awe for the world's Jews tend to be the days of "aww" for stock-market investors of any religion.

title: Kenneth Irving Is Shopping His 483-Acre Maine Retreat for $10 Million
summary: The former oil exec's property includes 7,700 feet of lake frontage, a 6,500-square-foot main house and a 250-square-foot cabin. In a tiny town in Maine, a member of one of Canada's richest families spent two decades creating a retreat complete with a suspension bridge to a swimming spot and a summer camp-like latrine for guests. Now he's putting the place on the market for $10 million.

title: Rust Belt City's Pitch for a Hot Housing Market: Free Homes
summary: Resume Subscription. Houses are more expensive than ever. Matt Shorraw is giving them away for free.

title: Science Fiction: The Swan Song of Sandman Slim
summary: The blade-wielding, fallen-angel guardian of L.A. faces down one more threat to his city.. Richard Kadrey's "Sandman Slim" sequence has to be the flagship of the urban fantasy subgenre. It started back in 2009, and now "King Bullet," the 12th novel in the series, is presented as the final installment.

title: A Highly Luxurious Maine Retreat for a Crowd
summary: On 483 acres, this lakefront property comes with sleeping porches and a summer camp-like latrine with multiple sinks and private water closets.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Money Manager Fell From First Row at the Met to a Prison Cell at Fort Dix
summary: Alberto Vilar, who has died at age 80, made huge pledges to support opera houses but then was accused of misusing clients' funds. During the tech-stock mania of the late 1990s, Alberto Vilar seemed to be one of the biggest winners. The cosmopolitan money manager's homes included a glittering 11,000-square-foot duplex apartment in Manhattan. He was a fixture in the world's great opera houses and pledged hundreds of millions of dollars to cultural institutions including New York's Metropolitan Opera and the Royal Opera House in London's Covent Garden.

title: China's Tencent to Make It Easier to Share Links to Rivals on WeChat
summary: After Beijing pressures tech giants, the messaging app will make it easier to share Alibaba listings. Tencent Holdings Ltd. said it would gradually remove some competitive barriers from its WeChat service, including making it easier for users to share e-commerce listings from major rival Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. on the messaging app.

title: 'Button': A Clothing Fastener Becomes a Virtual Trigger
summary: What we press on our smartphones is an image that mimics a mechanical object, a common sort of borrowing with information technology.. Linguist and lexicographer Ben Zimmer analyzes the origins of words in the news. Read previous columns here.

title: U.S. to Target Crypto Use in Ransomware Attack Payments
summary: Biden administration hopes to disrupt digital finance infrastructure that facilitates ransomware cyberattacks, a threat traced to Russia. The Biden administration is preparing an array of actions, including sanctions, to make it harder for hackers to use digital currency to profit from ransomware attacks, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Another Trade War, Another Stalemate?
summary: World trade is already struggling with high shipping costs and shuttered Asian factories. That might not prevent another ramp up in Sino-American trade tensions.. It is a risky time to launch a trade war: Supply chains are snarled, shipping costs are through the roof and the Delta variant is ravaging economies. The world just might get one anyway.

title: Invesco, Lucid, Diamondback: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Invesco jumps on merger talks, and traders watch out for "quadruple witching" in options and futures markets. Futures tied to the S&P 500 were down 0.1% early Friday, pointing to a subdued end to a choppy week in markets. It is a big options and futures contracts expiration day, known as "quadruple-witching," which often coincides with volatile trading. More than $750 billion of single-stock options expire Friday, according to analysts at Goldman Sachs.

title: United Airlines Briefly Grounds Flights in U.S., Canada
summary: Grounding lasted 45 minutes; technical system issues have been resolved. United Airlines Holdings Inc. grounded its flights in the U.S. and Canada Friday morning because of technical problems.

title: Networking Doesn't Have to Make You Feel Dirty
This Soccer Pro's Retirement Plan: Firefighting
summary: Houston Dash midfielder Christine Nairn's next move shows that many female athletes still need second careers-and she's making hers count. Christine Nairn's post-soccer plan is fire.

title: Hong Kong Considers Allowing SPAC Listings
summary: Exchange touts stringent framework as it launches public consultation on blank-check companies. Hong Kong is considering whether to allow listings of blank-check companies, potentially opening the doors to a wave of Chinese-focused deals involving special-purpose acquisition companies.

title: Covid-19 Rapid Testing in U.S. Lags Behind Other Countries in Delta Wave
summary: U.K., Germany widened availability of tests well-suited to tracking the contagious variant. The U.S. is behind the curve on rapid tests for Covid-19.

title: A French Book-Publishing Takeover Worthy of Netflix
summary: After a five-year activist campaign and a fight for control among rival billionaires, investors in both Lagardère and Vivendi finally get some clarity about the media businesses' futures. The long-running saga at French book publisher Lagardère may at last be drawing to a close. A takeover by media giant Vivendi would make a good ending for shareholders in the troubled company and start a new chapter for its suitor.

title: The Photographers Revealing Family Secrets
summary: Gillian Laub and Christopher Anderson discuss how they've turned their cameras on their own families, revealing the myriad rifts, heartbreaks and moments of beauty.. Photographers Gillian Laub and Christopher Anderson met over dinner in Manhattan some 20 years ago, where they spoke about the nature of family photography. At the time, Laub, now 46, was at the outset of a career as a portrait photographer and filmmaker that would lead her to prolonged stays in the American South and the Middle East, documenting communities far from her New York upbringing. Anderson, 51, was working as a freelance war photographer, traveling with refugees and shooting on the frontlines of conflict zones in Afghanistan, Niger and Haiti.

title: Monica Lewinsky's Blue Dress: How FX's 'Impeachment' Recreated the Infamous '90s Wardrobe
summary: The show's costume designer on creating historical replicas alongside show producer Lewinsky-as well as shopping Monica's closet.. Monica Lewinsky's blue Gap dress needs no introduction. But for the costume department of FX's Impeachment, that's what made it a real sartorial challenge.

title: How Facebook Hobbled Mark Zuckerberg's Bid to Get America Vaccinated
summary: Resume Subscription. In mid-March, Mark Zuckerberg used his Facebook page to announce a goal that was both ambitious and personal. He wanted his company to use its formidable resources to push 50 million people toward Covid-19 vaccines.

title: Facebook's Investors Are the Biggest Addicts
summary: They love what they can see but should care about what they can't. Anyone who thought Facebook just "woke up like this" need only read The Wall Street Journal's Facebook Files series this week to understand that things aren't so flattering right now beneath the surface. But even the harsh light of critical media reports hasn't been enough to scare away investors.

title: Biden Push to Replace America's Lead Pipes Faces Challenges
summary: Resume Subscription. CHICAGO-Marcelina Pedraza worries almost every time she turns on the faucet about the aging lead pipes that carry water into her home. But she says she can't afford to pay $15,000 or more, the city's estimated price tag, to replace them.

title: Should You Be Worried About Lead Pipes? What to Know
summary: Biden has promised to eliminate all lead pipes in the country's drinking-water system, but it could take decades. President Biden has said all lead pipes in the country's drinking-water system would be eliminated as part of his broader efforts to improve U.S. infrastructure.

title: California Recall Rules Enabling a Costly Election Spur Calls for Changes
summary: State Democratic leaders say century-old system curtails direct democracy and is in need of an overhaul. California's Democratic leaders want this week's gubernatorial recall election, which Gov. Gavin Newsom successfully fended off, to be the last of its kind in the state.

title: Australia Rethinks China Policy With Pivot to U.S. Submarines
summary: Canberra's new security partnership with the U.K. and Washington illustrates the sharp deterioration in diplomatic relations with Beijing. SYDNEY-Australia's move to own and operate nuclear-powered submarines with help from the U.S. reflects an increasingly prevalent view in the country that Canberra has misjudged China's rise and now needs to adopt a much more muscular strategy to counter Beijing's influence.

title: Universal's New Beijing Theme Park Will Ride on U.S.-China Ties
summary: Plans for the park date back decades, but it's now ready to open-at a low point in U.S.-China relations. BEIJING-Two decades in the making, one of the highest-profile American entertainment investments in China is set to make its public debut Monday, amid souring relations between the two countries.

title: Nicolas Cage as You've Never Seen Him...With Bombs Strapped Between His Legs
summary: The star of a new fantasy film that he compares to 'Conan the Barbarian' digs into what keeps him interested four decades into his movie career. At least from the moment he ate a live roach in 1988's "Vampire's Kiss," moviegoers have known that when they pay to see Nicolas Cage, they are probably going to get something weird.

title: iPhone Reality Doesn't Fully Ground Satellite Dreams
summary: Globalstar shares crash after iPhone 13 reveal but remain elevated as 'mystery project' continues. In the satellite world, what goes up doesn't usually come back down. The same can't be said for satellite stocks.

title: GPB Capital Founder Accused of Fraud Seeks Millions From Firm
summary: David Gentile is asking a judge to order mediation of his claim for more than $5 million. GPB Capital Holdings LLC founder David Gentile, who faces criminal and civil fraud charges related to how he ran the private-equity firm, is asking for court-supervised mediation to obtain millions of dollars he says GPB owes him as its general partner and owner.

title: Becoming a Starting Quarterback in College Is Sweet-While It Lasts
summary: Depth at the QB position is enabling top college teams to switch signal callers effortlessly when confronted by injuries or mediocre performances. Anthony Richardson wasn't supposed to wind up in the end zone. Standing on Florida's own 20 yard line, with his team up 22 points over South Florida, Richardson was meant to make a quick lateral to a wide open receiver. Instead, he ducked a charging defender, stiff-armed another and sprinted the remaining 80 yards for the score.

title: Energy Price Crunch Pushes Investors in Europe to Bet on Inflation
summary: Short-term market gauges of inflation expectations signal consumer prices to keep climbing. Record-breaking energy prices are driving bond investors to bet on a jump in eurozone inflation in the coming months, turning the trade bloc's narrative of superlow price growth on its head, at least temporarily.

title: China's Bid to Join TPP Trade Group Puts Members in an Awkward Spot
summary: The U.S. had an idea for a tariff-lowering club to limit the influence of Beijing's model, but now it's out and Xi Jinping wants in. TOKYO-A decade ago, it was a trade club led by the U.S. seeking to limit the influence of China's economic model. Now Washington is out of the Trans-Pacific Partnership and Beijing wants in-as the group's biggest member.

title: Democrats Want to Raise Taxes. Here's Your To-Do List.
summary: Consider making these moves before year-end to stay ahead of Uncle Sam. This week Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee voted to advance dozens of proposed tax changes. Some are tax increases that would raise more than $2 trillion of revenue to help fund the party's priorities.

title: Why Free Trading Will Never Be Free
summary: Some brokerage customers aren't happy that Robinhood and its rivals sell their orders. Even if regulators ban that practice, there are other ways no-commission brokerages can make money from your trades.. The payment-for-order-flow revenue model of brokerages like Robinhood Markets is in the crosshairs. But for many investors, the bigger question is what trading might look like without it.

title: China Missile Buildup Exposes Nuclear Spending Divide in Congress
summary: Missile modernization funds are likely to be included in annual defense funding bill expected to pass House this month. U.S. NUCLEAR MISSILE DEFENSES are in some cases decades old and in need of modernization, but congressional leaders and the military are at odds on how best to update the Cold War systems. Leading congressional Democrats want the military to review existing programs to make sure that updates to nuclear defenses are being done in cost-effective ways, while senior military leaders bemoan bureaucratic delays they say are creating strategic gaps with China. And on the other side of the aisle, some Republicans want to spend more on new missile defenses, including the possible installation of new silos in places like upstate New York.

title: China's Space Station Is Coming Together Bit by Bit
summary: Effectively barred from the International Space Station, China has embarked on an ambitious plan to build its own Earth-orbiting habitat. China aims to have its first space station up and running by next year.

title: Tallying Emissions Becomes a New Challenge for Companies
summary: Disclosures might be required soon on the amount of greenhouse gases released, but for now uniform reporting standards are lacking.

title: Lockdowns in Asia Deepen Commodity Supply-Chain Pain
summary: Palm-oil plantations and coffee farms struggle with labor shortages and transportation curbs as cases surge. The recent surge in Covid-19 cases in Southeast Asia has throttled ports and locked down plantations and processors, sparking extended disruptions of raw materials such as palm oil, coffee and tin.

title: Companies Grapple With Questions About Covid-19 Vaccine Mandate
summary: Biden administration's move renews debate about who should cover cost of testing for employees who don't want to get vaccinated. Companies preparing to implement the Biden administration's Covid-19 vaccine mandate face logistical challenges and unanswered questions about how to comply, employment and compensation lawyers say.

title: China Link Gives Hong Kong a Boost in Bond Trading
summary: The southbound Bond Connect aims to draw more issuers and investors from mainland China to the city's markets. Hong Kong is likely to become a bigger center for trading and issuing bonds, thanks to a program that will further open the market to mainland Chinese investors.

title: Chinese Astronauts Complete Country's Longest Stay in Space
summary: Trio of taikonauts spent three months helping build China's rival to the International Space Station. HONG KONG-A trio of Chinese astronauts landed back on Earth on Friday after three months in space, setting a record for the country's longest stay in orbit as China pursues an ambitious space program.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: CEO's Father Gets a $3.6 Billion Stock Windfall at Carvana
summary: Selling spree from chief executive's dad highlights corporate structure that benefits family. Aside from Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg and members of Walmart Inc.'s Walton family, no individual has earned more from selling stock in their company over the past year than a used-car magnate from Arizona.

title: I Was Saving a Lot of Money During Lockdown. But Then It All Changed.
summary: One problem: It's hard to keep track of all the online spending we're doing.. In the early days of the pandemic lockdown, I could barely recognize myself. I looked like me, but over the course of spring and summer of 2020, it seemed my financial self was in the best shape he had ever been-so much so that I felt guilty about it.

title: Should You Buy an iPhone 13? Check Your Current Phone-and Pick the Best Upgrade
summary: Use this interactive chatbot to help decide whether to get one of Apple's new models, based on your needs and your current device. Now that Apple's newly announced iPhone 13 lineup is available for pre-order, you might be looking at your older phone and wondering if it's time for a change. Our reviews of the new phones are coming soon-but we're hoping this guide will help you determine whether you should upgrade at all, and which of the four iPhone 13 models would likely fit your preferences.

title: France Calls U.S.-Australia Submarine Deal a Betrayal
summary: French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian says U.S. move to step in a 'stab in the back'. France said it had been betrayed by the U.S. after being pushed out of a multibillion-dollar deal to supply submarines to Australia, in a public rupture between NATO allies that is shaping up to be among the most bitter trans-Atlantic disputes of the Biden administration's first year.

title: China Wants Gig Workers to Have More Power-Just Not Too Much
summary: Unionization push and new algorithm rules could help workers, but activists and scholars say Beijing's ultimate aim is greater control. HONG KONG-China's communist state has made a show in recent months of supporting the lowest-level workers in the country's bare-knuckle tech industry, an emerging plank in leader Xi Jinping's campaign to shrink the country's wealth gap and usher in a new era of "common prosperity."

title: GOP Rep. Anthony Gonzalez Won't Seek Re-Election
summary: Ohio congressman was one of 10 Republicans who voted to impeach Trump after the Jan. 6 Capitol riot. WASHINGTON-GOP Rep. Anthony Gonzalez of Ohio said Thursday night that he won't run for re-election next year, the first of the 10 House Republicans who voted to impeach former President Donald Trump to do so.

title: Ex-Boeing Pilot Expected to Face Prosecution in 737 MAX Probe
summary: Investigators looked into Mark Forkner's role in alleged efforts to mislead air-safety regulators. Federal prosecutors plan to criminally charge a former Boeing Co. pilot they suspect of misleading aviation regulators about safety issues blamed for two fatal crashes of the 737 MAX, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: SpaceX Inspiration4 Crew Wraps Up First Day in Space
summary: All-civilian mission conducts scientific research and places two sports bets. The first all-civilian crew to orbit the Earth traveled nearly six times around the planet during the mission of Elon Musk's company, SpaceX.

title: California Limits Single-Family Home Zoning
summary: Law intended to increase housing supply and lower prices will allow duplexes on properties where one home exists. California Gov. Gavin Newsom has signed legislation allowing the construction of duplexes on most properties with one home, a severe curtailing of single-family zoning in a state struggling with some of the nation's highest housing prices.

title: Sports Court Upholds Doping Ban for Former Nike Coach Alberto Salazar
summary: The Court of Arbitration for Sport confirmed several violations by Salazar and a doctor who worked with Nike athletes. An international sports court upheld the four-year doping suspension of former Nike Inc. elite running coach Alberto Salazar, but declined to extend it as requested by the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency.

title: Biden Steps Up Efforts to Advance $3.5 Trillion Spending Bill
summary: The president met with two centrist senators and defended his plans to increase taxes on high-income households and U.S. companies. WASHINGTON-President Biden is taking a more public role in the negotiations around Democrats' roughly $3.5 trillion social welfare and climate bill, as lawmakers work through thorny policy debates.

title: Minnesota Supreme Court Allows Initiative on Replacing Minneapolis Police Onto Ballot
summary: High court reverses lower court ruling that barred voting on proposal stemming from killing of George Floyd. The Minnesota Supreme Court on Thursday reversed a lower court's decision to strike down a proposed ballot initiative asking voters to replace the Minneapolis Police Department with a new public safety agency.

title: Lawyer Michael Sussmann Indicted on Charges of Lying to FBI
summary: Grand jury's action arises from special counsel John Durham's investigation into origins of agency's Russia probe. WASHINGTON-A grand jury has indicted a high-profile cybersecurity lawyer in connection with special counsel John Durham's investigation into the origins of the FBI's Russia probe, on charges that he lied to investigators during the 2016 presidential campaign.
